TESS.raw_line: Once upon a time ...a long, looong time ago... there was a good little girl...and they called her... REVEAL ...TESS. A stunner with impossibly long lashes, theatrical make-up and a sequined, skin-tight band-aid of a dress. She works the tight stage of the club, toying with the AUDIENCE.Burlesque. MUSIC BLARES from a HOT YOUNG BUMPER BAND -- sax, drums, bass -- wearing bowler hats, suspenders and lots of ink. The crowd HOOTS. Lame streamers EXPLODE from the stage.Some say she up and died-of neglect. Abandonment.But I say...no matter how hard you try, you can't keep a good girl down. And I've got a bevy of 'em.Come to think of it, none of them are all that good, which isn't all that bad... SEAN , a cute gay guy with an armful of accessories pushes his way through the girls and in a blur, tightens a corset, tosses a boa, adjusts a garter just so.Eight shows a week. Sixteen gorgeous girls. Thirty-two towers of luscious legs...Say hello to Scarlett. Jesse. Anna. Coco-puff. And Georgie-Girl. The girls gather at the edge of the stage, lit by footlights, moving in place to the beat of the INTRO MUSIC. Hips sway. Fingers snap. Tess weaves playfully between them.All of them the creme-de la creme.Each one a bastion of bodacious... Elegance. TWO GIRLS upside down on chairs NAIL aerial splits.Not to mention their other... Ass-ets. Coco raises a brow, moves her butt to a LOUD BUMP-AND-GRIND.Welcome to the Burlesque Lounge, dead smack in the center of the Sunset Strip-- did I say "strip?" I meant TEASE... FOOTLIGHTS FLARE, UPLIGHTING THE GIRLS. They shift their weight, hitting the beats with risque moves and hip-thrusts as they MOVE DOWNSTAGE suggestively toward the audience to the MUSIC...The insatiable La Puccini Triplets! Death-defying daredevils Missy and Kitten DeVille! The Countess of contortion, Eva Destruction! And how about a little love for those bad boys of burlesque, our naughty- bawdy bumber band! THE TATTOOED BAND blares as the troupe kicks in unisonWhere the hell is Nikki?Jesus, Nikki, you're later than Georgia's period! Where were you?Hold it right there. Weigh in. Nikki unwillingly steps on the scale. Tess shakes her head.Put on five pounds or I bump you. Nikki protests as Sean double-takes at Georgia -- who FLITS BY with a slightly protruding belly.Girls look good tonight.They're loving you.Eat me. As he heads off with her discarded costume:Half-full.And you told him we weren't selling.Vince, I don't care what the number is; the only way Marcus Gerber will get this club from me is by prying it out of my cold, dead, heavily- jeweled fingers. She pivots away and sweeps into the club.Smoother than honey and twice as sweet. Each girl lovelier then the next. Gentlemen, hold onto your hats. Ladies, hold on to your gentlemen. We may not have windows.. .but we DO have the best view on the Sunset Strip! MUSIC KICKS IN AS LIGHTS FLARE from the back of the stage, where Three Girls stand, backs to the audience, Fosse-style. Coco, Georgia, and Nikki strut downstage. Behind them, Girls MOVE AND DANCE on cabaret chairs. Totally raunchy, completely timeless.So am I. And sometimes, when the lights are dim, and I squint my eyes ...I can still see her. She switches to mascara. Sean, arms heavy with corsets, catches eyes with Ali, nods toward Tess: "that's her." Ali steps closer to Tess.New in town.Looking for a job.Want to perform here.This is a dance show.Really? You a professional?Not on my dime. Tess stands, a final check in the mirror. Ali sees her chanceTwenty bucks at the door can make all your dreams come true. Tess strides out, not looking back. Ali sees the Girls trading glances, amused. She turns and leaves.Nikki, do you even own a watch? Or do you measure time in Patron shots? Ali enters with a tray of drinks. Nikki swipes one.Fast-forward, babe. I gotta rebuild Rome in the next two minutes--Just one?"When burlesque started"? Which was...when?Vaudeville -- is the word you're looking for. Derived from the 15th- century French expression "voix de ville" -- "voice of the city". Popular songs of the time that were strung together into stage shows. Which, over time, gave birth to another kind of show in which talented girls showing a bit more skin danced, did skits, and, _ yes, sang. In addition to being raunchier, these shows were funnier, hence the new name. "Burlesque": "comical" in French. Ali sees the Girls enjoying this dressing-down immensely. Tess stands, peers down her nose at Ali.Dance major. Juilliard. I did my thesis on Burlesque.We can all sing. But they don't come to hear us sing. They come to see the best dancers in town backed by the greatest singers in history. But tell you what: when you find someone with better pipes than Sarah Vaughn, Billie Holiday and Etta James-- you let me know. She sashays out leaving Ali standing there with what's left of her dignity and an empty cocktail tray. The Girls launch back into prepping for the show.Okay, front row, thank you very much. They walk off stage, dismissed. Tess turns to Sean.What happened to all the great dancers in L.A?All right, ladies, and five, six, seven -- whoa. There, in the back row, is Ali, in her white platform shoes.What the hell do you think you're doing? Coco and Georgia ENTER-- surprised to see Ali on stage.I don't think so.The girls here have years of training and experience. This stage is for serious and professionalTough Lover! Tess plops down in a booth-- crosses her arms indignantly. ON STAGE, the music starts. Ali readies herself, starts to dance. Behind a beat to two. She's got the steps right, but it isn't clicking. She's thinking too hard. No personality. After a few measures, Tess has seen enough.Okay then, next?I want so badly to say something bitchy, but nothing's coming.You were off the whole second half.Oh, you're gonna be such a pain in my ass. Ali tries hard not to beam--You're not great. What you are is lucky. Because I need someone tonight.Even in those shoes that time forgot.Your brush is for shit. She turns and sees Tess in the doorway. Tess comes over, takes Ali's brush. Looks at it.Where'd you get this, the 99 cent store? She chucks it in the trash.Make-up is like wine. The good stuff costs a fortune but is worth every penny. Where is everyone?Aren't you one of the girls?Don't take it personally. Their love's the kind you gotta earn. Ali meets her eyes in the mirror. Then Tess grabs a brush from her own station, tosses it to Ali.Dip it in water first, or you'll never get a clean line. She leaves Ali alone.So I said to the sailor, I may not be as good as I once was...But you can bet your sweet ass I'm better ONCE than I ever was... The crowd laughs. Tess points to a woman who isn't laughing.Drink up, sister! You're a tad behind. Be a dear and bring Mommy over there another scotch. The crowd chuckles as the Bumper Band kicks in and the harem scene evolves into a sexy tongue-in-cheek silhouetted dance.Ply him with drinks, send Scarlett over to flirt, and try to finagle him down to a half.Have I told you lately that I love you?Drinking already?You're drunk.I'm pulling you from this number. Go home, wring yourself out, and come back tomorrow.Ali! Take Nikki's spot.Ali-- get dressed NOW! Ali looks at Nikki-- who GLARES at her--But this is MY club, and now it's your number. Ali looks between the two of them, Nikki glaring at her--Is there a problem? You said you know the whole show.Close the Goddman curtain!Do you boys know all the music?Okay, then. Tomorrow night, Ali sings lead, everyone else is back- up. Questions? Ali can't keep from beaming as she shakes her head, no!Good. The Girls file into the dressing room. Tess heads out, past Nikki.No. But they'll come to hear her sing. Dry out and maybe you can back her up. She leaves. Nikki scowls. Sean grabs Ali.What did he want?Vince, if I were going to sell, I'd have sold to those idiots building that monstrosity across the street. I said no.Why do you want this club so badly?Do you know what you can do with that money, Vince?Did you also tell him about the tattoo on my ass?My business. Which I built from the ground up.Exactly. She looks at a photo on her wall: the Burlesque Girls, in all their glory.Which is why I'll never let it go. She gets up, opens the door, ushering them out. Marcus shoots Vince an angry look as they head downstairs. IN THE STAIRWELL, Vince reassures Marcus:No. You cannot say that to me. I can eat these "sky is falling" dipshits for breakfast, lunch, and dinner, but not YOU. You cannot be that person. I've scoured dirty flea markets for costumes, stayed up all night sewing till my fingers bled, painted and repainted every goddamn wall of this place myself.I choreographed every step of every number. I've played nursemaid, sister, mother and shrink to every girl who's ever danced here. I've hocked every keepsake I've ever owned to keep this place afloat. Because this club is the last of it's kind, and if it goes away, one day there won't be anything like it- - and THAT would be a tragedy. So you cannot say that to me. Because now someone's gotta believe in me, Goddamnit. And I need that person to be you. So don't you ever let me hear you say that again. I will never let this club go. Never. Sean looks at her...a wry smile.Coco-puff, shake a leg, you're on in five, Georgie-Girl, Ali-Cat -- move, move, move -- Tess exits.Can you believe this crowd? He dumps the costumes in her arms.Can you believe the crowd out there? Never thought I'd see- She stops in her tracks, spotting Vince's PANTS on the FLOOR, and a TRAIL OF WOMEN'S CLOTHES to... THE NEW COCKTAIL WAITRESS, peering out, half-dressed, from behind the curtains--Not now, Nikki.I'll get her to write a check tomorrow.No, it's not her show. It's my show. But people want to hear her sing. She's bringing them in off the streets. You better believe I'm building a show around her!Nikki, you're wasted. Go home.So don't be! Leave! If you don't want to be a part of what's happening here, then I don't want you around.Since when do you care about friendship? Or this group? You're a trainwreck, Nikki! You put tequila on your breakfast cereal! I'm struggling to survive here, and you show up too drunk to dance! You call that loyalty? Nikki just looks at her--Night, Dave. Dave FLIPS a big lever, and almost all the lights go OUT, leaving one shaft of light across the stage. We HEAR Dave leave, as the street door closes shut. Tess alone on stage.Right now? Get really drunk. THE FRONT DOORS OPEN, and Ali ENTERS, spots Tess, rushes over to her.Smoother than honey and twice as sweet. Each girl lovelier then the next. Gentlemen, hold onto your hats. Ladies, hold on to your gentlemen. We may not have windows.. .but we DO have... .the best view on the Sunset Strip. The audience hoots as the Burlesque Girls ENTER the stage dancing. ON ALI-- a lightbulb going on! As Tess exits the stage, Ali pushes through the crowd and races backstage.You could knock-- this is still my office--at least for another 48Not. Now.I said -- NOT --You offered to buy my club a few years back. I said no.Not exactly. Tess smiles at him. Looks at Ali, who's not smiling. She elbows her. Ali starts smiling. Tess walks up to the desk and sits herself down. Ali does the same.Go with me, there's a good ending, I promise. How much will these condos you're building sell for?What if I told you a twenty-story high-rise was going up where my club is?So. Mr. ?Mr. Anderson. Your pretty million- dollar ocean views are going away because I'm selling my building to a developer tomorrow who'll have his twenty stories all framed up by the time you start selling --Trying to sell these condos.As am I. As long as you're telling me you'll have a check to me by 5:00 today.Not anymore you don't. I'm buying you out.Actually, according to page 4 of our contract, I can.Why postpone joy? She hands him a CASHIER'S CHECK. Vince stares at it.I realize it's been a while since you've seen one, but it's called a check. He stares at it, stunned.Then at her.Not your business anymore. And neither is the lounge.Not half bad.It felt pretty God damn awesome! And they crack up again. Then...Oh, Jesus, here it comes.Are you finished?All right already! You want me to say it, I'll say it. She looks at her.This place is the love of my life. The only dream I've ever had. I don't know what I would have done if I had lost it.Again.What do you think? Tess and Nikki share a look.Curtain's up in 20. Shake a leg. Nikki smiles, hikes her dance bag over her shoulder and headsIf I had a dollar for every time she's quit...We all fight. Bitch. Love and hate. And then make up. Just like sisters.Me neither. THANK GOD.Now get your cute little ass and big ole' voice up on stage, cause this is Burlesque, baby girl, where the women are always on top, and the men like it that way. Like I've always said --

ALI.raw_line: Uh, excuse me? You forgot something. He turns. Sees: ALI ROSE. One hand holding a bar rag, the other planted on her hip. Ali has a look that's all her own: short shorts, white platform sandals, hair piled up high, more make-up than the rest of Grundy's women combined. She's young -- 22 -- but has a confidence that's got nothing to do with age.Huh. See, now that's interesting -- you and I must do math completely differently, cause me? I start with the six beers I brought you, add the four spills I cleaned up, the five times I refilled your peanuts, plus the three times you "accidentally" touched my ass, then I tack on lying to your wife when she called looking for you, twice, and I come up with a sum that's a hell of a lot more than twenty-five cents. Before the Regular can respond, Ali is joined by LORETTA -- 30's wearing every one of those years hard.Nothin's cheap. A quarter's an insult.There's only one thing a quarter is good for. Ali takes the quarter and heads to the back of the room, passing a GEEZER who's sitting by himself, drinking alone.Dwight isn't here. Ali stops in front of the rinky-dink karaoke machine.Tough. I'm not working here for the tips Loretta. She pops the quarter into the machine and chooses a song. She picks up the microphone and, after a few opening beats, starts singing ETTA JAMES'S "SOMETHING'S GOT A HOLD ON ME".Loretta-- when I get out of this butt-hole of a town, I sure as shit won't be heading for Des Moines. She hops up onto the bar, spins around on her butt, one leg up in the air like a Varga girl, then hops down on the other side then gets back to work.Nanna? Got your pot roast here!They were out of steak fries, so I got you some of those... Then she stops in her tracks. Nanna -- 80's, housecoat, oxygen tank -- is slumped in her chair. The TV remote is on the floor. "ENTERTAINMENT TONIGHT" is blaring.Nanna?Arlene.She's Arlene. I'm Alison.No, she was good to me. JACK - 25, punky, dark hair, eyeliner, one arm half-sleeved with tats.Welcome to L.A.You still have that new-car smell.Where you from? She looks back at the stage, mesmerized.Oh, yeah? Kentucky. We're practically related.Hey_. Go.They don't build 'em like this in Iowa, huh?Is this you flirting?Ask for Tess. She's your guy. Flirt away. As she heads off--Hey, Iowa-- use my name. He hands her a card. She looks at it:Yeah, Coco's the real deal.She used to dance with the Joffrey Ballet. Nikki sang opera. Eva performed with Cirque. Everyone here's a pro. And you're on!Dewar's rocks, bottle of Dom, keep it coming.Marcus Gerber. Real estate guy.This week. Vince goes over to Marcus's table, shakes hands, joins him.Technically your boss: Vince Scali. Tess's partner. And ex... Jack is about to lift the AmEx off the tray, when Sean swoops by and intercepts it.Ali? What's wrong? You okay? She tries to speak, but can't -- so she just nods.Really? Cause, in my experience-- when you're on someone's doorstep surrounded by everything you own, there's usually a not-so-good storyShit. No way!Okay. I have no idea what you just said, but come on in here and we'll get it sorted out. She looks at him. Wiping her tears. He picks up the heaviest of her bags and leads her to:Have a seat. I'll get us BOTH a drink. Here -- He hands her his phone. She looks at it.-- call whoever you want, long- distance, whatever--Sure you can. Go ahead. Her chin starts quivering all over again.What do you mean?No parents? Siblings? Aunts? Uncles?Okay. Wait. No, stop, stop, stop, it's okay, it's fine. You'll crash here. No problem. Just, please -- no more crying. She nods. He grabs a bottle of Tequila and a couple of glasses. Pours them a couple. They both take a drink.Better? She nods.Okay. Good. She wipes her eyes.Deal. Then she opens her small bag and the cat strolls out.Whoa, whoa, you didn't say anything about a cat.I hate cats.It's easy, I'll show you. The cat bolts into the bedroom.Where's it going? If that thing pees on my bed --One night?Thanks.Make more money bartending.Was... Guitarist moved to Reno, Drummer went to med school, bassist is in rehab. I'm subbing around town till I regroup. This is for a punk fusion band -- their keyboardist is a flake, so they call me a lot.Why'd you leave Iowa?Exactly. A beat. Then as he starts playing again:Get some sleep.Aauuuugggghh. He hurls the cat away and bolts out of bed, disgusted.My fiancee. Natalie.Of course I'm straight. You thought I was gay?Why?It's a look.A straight look.Probably. She bolts out to the living room, starts digging through her bag, bent over. She's in the doorway, so from the kitchen, all he can see is her cute little ass sticking out.New York. Doing a play.Six more weeks. She can't find pants. She shifts, so now her ass is facing him directly. He tries not to look--For what?Well, you did, and it was fine. Aha! Pants. She pulls them out, starts putting them on. He looks out. Her foot is caught in the pants leg. As she hops around, trying to untangle it--Or at least it will be as soon as you get dressed. She tumbles out of view, thumps against some furniture. She appears in the doorway, pants on, pulling on a sweater. She slips her feet into her shoes.Wait, where're you headed?Hang on, let me at least spot you some cash. I'm a little strapped, but I could --Cool. She leaves. He closes the door behind her. Stands there.So, this plan of yours?Come back inside.It's pouring!Look, you have nowhere to go, I have a couch. You may as well stay here for a few days.You'll be homeless. You always have this much trouble saying yes when someone is trying to help you?There's a towel in the bathroom-- dry yourself and that damn cat off.Your stupid cat peed in the tub!Your cat pees in the house, and it's my_ fault?! Ali scoops the cat up.Goddamn cat. And you used my towel again. How's that apartment hunting coming? He GRABS the newspaper and tosses it in front of her-- she glares at him, then glances at the paper--Can you really put a price on privacy? Freedom? Your own bathroom? With clean towels?Natalie. Hey, baby, how are you? He heads into the bedroom, closes the door. Ali shakes her head, begins to peruse the classifieds.Go to Hell, turn left, it's three miles down on the right.Great, if you have a car.I'm gonna suck it up and let you stay here a little longer. Just throw in a little something for rent. She looks at him, curious.Hey, I don't like the cat. And I don't like my towel being wet. I don't like the lack of privacy. But you're in a jam -- and I'm the kind of guy, if a friend's in trouble, I help. It's just who I am.Nothing, you know just... hi. She narrows her eyes at him. He concedes.And...her play got extended three more months, so since she has to pay rent there, she can't also keep up her part of the rent here.So if you could stick around and chip in, it would ---- help. Ali looks down at his shoes.Just -- yes or no?The bedroom, with private bathroom access, for 600 a month, including utilities.Half . Ali picks up the paper, reads an ad.Fine. The closet, too. She weighs it. Makes him suffer. Then:Thank you.You blew me away! Who knew you could sing like that?What?I have a fiancee.We talk every day.Night. Sean EXITS as Jack carries a stack of chairs to the side of the room, sets them down near the piano. STOPS, grabs a chair for himself and sits down. Begins to play an original song. ACROSS THE ROOM, Ali ENTERS from backstage. Her dance bag over her shoulder. She HEARS the piano, peers around a column, SEES Jack playing. She stays in the shadows and watches as he sings and plays a beautiful song. The song ends. Ali applauds slowly. Impressed. Jack looks up, surprised that she is there.Just some sentimental crap. Ready?Hey! Just got home! Ali grabs a dress from her bed, slips into it.Rehearsing. I'm playing a late show tonight. As he zips up the back of her dress, he sees the PHOTO propped against the lamp on the bedside table.Who is that? She picks up the picture. Looks at it.She was so young.Wow. You must miss her. She puts the photo down. Turns back to him. They're close.What was today's? A beat. Their eyes connect.I should... it's... Natalie. Ali steps away from him, disappointed. He answers the phone.Hey, babe, how are you? Ali watches him walk away from her, falling into the conversation with Natalie.Yes, she's still here-What do you want me to do, it's not like you're here helping out, you know...I have that gig, remember? In fact, I gotta head out or I'm gonna be late. I can maybe swing you home before.By the way -- you killed.Ali? He looks in. Empty. He checks the clock: 4:45. He hears a "meow", and sees the cat. He picks it up, turns out the light, and leaves the room.You were out late last night.Marcus the Asshole?New shoes?There's only one reason a man buys a woman shoes, you know.You get a lot more than a little.Hey. Have you seen this?Little overdressed for breakfast.Well, you're never here so... it's stupid for me to crash on the couch every night when there's a perfectly good empty bed. Jack grinds the coffee beans again. Ali winces.The bed should be used by someone.Fine.You'll have to move all your shit.Cause the room's a total mess --Clothes, make-up, shoes, hair things.What? No. What do I care? You're ambitious, he can make things happen, go ahead, make a deal with the devil, what's it to me?And try not to kill the cat!What do you mean, you're still in New York? ...So you just -- decided not to come? You think you might've wanted to, I don't know, let me know??? We haven't seen each other in six months. ACROSS THE TERRACE, Ali sees Jack yelling into his phone. Sean sees her watching..why does every conversation we have end up being about YOUR future... Jack looks across the terrace at Ali. Moonlight on her shoulders. A breeze in her hair..you know what, you're right. We both should be thinking about our futures. And I might just be looking at mine right now. Break a leg baby. Jack hangs up with finality and marches toward the bar-- His cell phone immediately rings again.I guess Natalie's not coming after all.You still mad at me, Iowa? C'mon. Bring it on. She starts to say something as-- THE SHIRELLES start to sing "BABY IT'S YOU"-- Jack turns to the DJ, points both fingers at him and YELLS:.Many many many nights go by, I sit alone, at home and cry, over you...I'm sorry for being a class A prick. Ali smiles, surprised at his candor. He breathes a sigh of relief.And as of about... (bleary look at his watch,That we did. So. That explains what I'm doing here all alone. What are you doing here all alone?Whoopsie daisy?Upsie jumpsie? Upsie jumpsie, whoopsie daisy, upsie jumpsie, whoopsie daisy, upsie jumpsie --The dog, or Nanna? Ali bursts out laughing. So does Jack, as he pushes the door open, and they fall into the apartment.Stay. He turns back to Ali, regains composure, bowsGood night. He backs away, into the bedroom. Ali looks confused.A gift from my mother. Never worn them.Forgot to lock up.Water. No hangover. He stumbles past Ali to the kitchen, drinks from the tap. After a moment he returns to the bedroom, nodding to Ali.Night. Ali just nods. He closes the door. Ali smiles, waiting. After a beat, the door opens again. Jack is there, in boxers.Hungry. He walks past her to the kitchen, opens a box of cereal, pours it into his mouth. Grabs some milk from the fridge, pours it into his mouth, too. Returns to the bedroom, crunching. He closes the door. Then -- very quickly -- he opens it again and walks out.I know I forgot something else, but I just can't remember what...What's so funny? She covers her face. He glances down.Well I never! He strides back to the bedroom, shutting the door. After a moment, he comes back out dressed in an old, flowered bathrobe and fur-lined orange hunting cap.I remembered what I forgot to do.What?I've been wanting to do this since you first walked in the club. She cocks an eyebrow at him.I'll show you an even funnier way -- you ready? He disappears under the sheets. She SQUEALS, starts laughing hysterically. CAMERA PANS UP AND OFF OF THEM THEN DRIFTSNatalie who? Ali smiles. Rolls the stocking up over her shapely thigh, then slowly takes it off. Looks at Jack. He strikes his chest, struck by cupid--Do it again. She giggles, repeats the sexy act for him. CAMERA PANS UP ANDNatalie! Ali blinks awake. Confused.I don't know!Nat, can we talk about this in the living room --Listen, Ali-- let me just-- would you mind --Giving us a little privacy?Natalie, Jesus, STOP IT! Ali grabs some pants from the floor, pulls them on.Both of you-- STOP IT! As Ali quickly grabs a few things--Ali-- I'm really sorry-- I--Wait-- do you need money for a Motel or... Ali stifles him with an incredulous glare-- can't believe how this is going down. She looks at him, so incredibly hurt. Grabs her suitcase and brushes past him, stuffing her belongings into it. Jack goes after her--Ali, wait a second-- don't-- --go.Is Ali here?Where'd she go?What?What are you doing here?I have to. I got an offer from that band -- the Punk Fusion group. They want me to tour with them.They finally had it with the flaky keyboardist. I'll be back in five weeks. Will you be here?What about Marcus?I'm trying to figure out if I should kiss you now, or make you wait five weeks.I gotta go, that's me. He picks up his bags. It's killing Ali.I'll call you when I get there. Take care of Miles Davis. Our cat. I named him. They smile again. Neither wanting this moment to end. She waves. He nods. Then he turns and walks off to board. Ali watches him go. ON JACK, walking back to the gate-then -- he stops. Turns back to see Ali, but she's gone.But then I'll miss my flight!

MARCUS.raw_line: Dewar's on the rocks for me. Bottle of Dom for the table and-- --And tell Nikki I'm here. Ali starts away, then--A member since 1991. Oh-kay. He smiles, wickedly handsome. Ali pivots and heads back to the bar. Before she can tell Jack the order:That's what you said last time.There's a handful of these clubs around town, I could buy one of them tomorrow.Where'd you learn to sing like that? She turns. Marcus is there. Handsome, charming and devious as ever.Well, you're too good to be singing here.How about a drink?But I hate lines. AT THE BAR - Jack looks up, SEES Ali and Marcus talking. BACK ON MARCUS who looks Ali up and down.Seriously. You sound even better than you look. Which is saying a lot.It's very simple. I buy you out and pay you a million off the top. Five hundred grand each. Tess looks up from the contract, squints at Marcus.Best view on the Sunset Strip.The club's not even worth what you paid for it. You've got a second mortgage, you can't get a third. Tess looks at Vince, betrayed.You're not gonna get another opportunity like this.You ready?I'll drop you off.Sorry-- I was coming to talk to you and caught the end of your conversation.Dinner. With me. Gimmie that. He swoops down and GRABS her dance bag and purse, turns and heads out.I told you-- to dinner.We're friends.Aren't you glad you left? Oh, damn!I just remembered I have to make a quick appearance at a party.It's on the way. We'll be quick. Ten minutes, tops. Do you mind?Then you've been kidnapped. He turns off Sunset and heads up into the hills.Hey, how you doing? He shakes the guy's hand and moves on through the party. Someone else calls out to him.Hey, let me get a drink, I'll beNot if we sneak out first, come on. He kicks open a back door.Up there. He starts up some steps to an outdoor gazebo. Ali follows. They pass AN INCREDIBLY WELL-DRESSED COUPLE coming down.Hey, Guys. Greg, Marla, this is Ali. They exchange hellos. Ali notices:Glad you could come. Ali stares at Marcus. He smiles, takes her hand, keeps leading her up the stairs.Would've been rude not to, right? You'd like those guys. Greg's the entertainment editor at the Times, and Marla's a designer. Ali glances back at Marla again, locks in on her shoes.Thousand dollars a pop.I can.It should. That view cost me three times what the house did.No. I own everything above it.Exactly.Air rights. The guy who owns the strip mall was having money issues and almost had to sell. Whoever he sold to would have put in a huge tower. So I bought the air rights. Now no one can ever build above one story.Mall guy gets to keep his property. I get to keep the second best view in L.A.None who ever called me on it. He smiles. Looks at her. Then...What do you want, Ali? In life. Girl like you, gives up everything, gets on a bus heading for total uncertainty-- she's got a dream. I want to know what it is.Because you're talented enough to get whatever you want. And I'm smart enough to help make it happen. So? What do you want? A beat. She thinks about it. Looks him in the eye.That's ...so beautiful.Why do you women always take advantage of nice boys?To the girl of the hour.This has NOTHING to do with Tess. This is about you. And me.I've got another friend I want you to meet. She sees HAROLD SAINT sitting in the booth. He's in his 60's, still dressing like Robert Evans in his heyday.Ali Rose, Harold Saint.Hey gorgeous.Who's that?Should I be jealous?You okay? You sound down.I know just the cure.Me. But you turned me down. She thinks for a moment. Then:My mother always said there's only one thing to do when you're feeling blue... He opens the fridge and pulls out a bottle of CHAMPAGNE.And a drunk. Ali smiles. Marcus pops the cork, fills two glasses, hands her one. Clinks.To your new place.All yours. Unpack. Move in.Sure you can. Marcus plops her suitcase on the bed.Unpack. You're home.Okay, that is the first and last time the term "bus route" will be spoken in this house. Four cars. Which do you want?Better?You're gonna be on one of those someday.Sooner than you think, too. Harold Saint called me today. You made quite an impression on him.He wants to make a demo with you.He found a little studio time on Tuesday.Too soon?I like making you happy. Your whole face lights up. Their eyes meet. He pushes some hair out of her face.And that's a problem because...Hey, I'm a gentleman. Which means I'd never kiss a lady when she's... vulnerable.Morning.Now it's a model. But when it grows up, it'll be a mixed-use space: retail and residential.Best view on the Sunset Strip, with no windows. When I'm done with it, it'll have a thousand.Actually, I can.Not according to the city.What Tess knows and doesn't know isn't a big concern of mine.She has no choice. She's going under.Oh, come on, you get this. It's business. It's not personal.Where are you going?Ali-- wait!!! At the door she turns back and looks at him. As he starts to speak, she SLAMS the door shut as we HEAR "THAT'S LIFE".
